div.head: W.J. Conyers Yearbook Comment 1858
div.p: It gives me much happiness to enroll my name on the list of acquaintances whom you wish especially wish to remember. While it grieves me deeply to know that another and a dear friend is soon to depart; yet it I cannot but esteem into a great privalege priviledge to leave with him something, which however humble it may be, cannot help but recall the friend of his College course.

Our acquaintance has been comparitively short but of sufficient duration to bind us by other cords than those of mere acquaintance; such I am sure as shall prove sternley oburate to the force of time and its attendant circumstances. But soon you must leave us to sip the sweets or battle with "the stern realities of life", and I cannot repress my heartfelt wishes for your happiness. May your sound worth and strict integrity secure to you the purest pleasures and joys of life unmingled with any of its perplexing cares. I would have your pathway continue smooth, your sky unclouded, your stream unruffled. But whether you revel in life's enjoyments or be tortured by its amenities remember, yes forget not your classmate.
